RT @FoundationFAR Tune in now to hear FFAR Board member Dan Glickman and others testify before the Senate Committee On Agriculture, Nutrition & Forestry about the role that agricultural research plays in securing the US food supply: https://www.agriculture.senate.gov/hearings/agricultural-research-and-securing-the-united-states-food-supply

RT @SenateAgDems Stabenow to @SenPatRoberts: For our last hearing together, it‚Äôs only fitting that we reflect on one of the most impactful issues we have worked on together: #AgResearch and the important role it plays in protecting our food supply.
RT @SenateAgDems Stabenow starts by recognizing Chairman @SenPatRoberts‚Äô leadership: I know your legacy will live on through the words you‚Äôve written into law. #AgResearch

Roberts: There is no doubt we are in a better place today because those who came before us recognized the need for research and innovation in ag. I look forward to hearing from our panel about what these past efforts have meant, and more important, where we should we go from here

Roberts: It is vital that we have the necessary authorities, capabilities, and scientific understanding of zoonotic diseases, like COVID-19, to prevent and combat diseases, protect the food production & supply chain, and meet the nutrition needs of a growing & changing population

Roberts: The #FarmBill also established new authorities & investments to bolster research & scientific understanding related to the security of our food supply. Authorities like AGARDA allow USDA to carry out research and develop cutting-edge technologies and research tools.

Roberts: In a period of tight budgets and flat-lined discretionary spending, the 2018 #FarmBill, with 87 votes of support, provided an increase of $780 million in mandatory funding for agricultural research over 10 years.

Roberts: There is still a great deal to do. We must take a fresh look at what ag security means in terms of the defense of the ag sector and our food supply. This begins with continued support for ag research, a priority in all of the 8 farm bills that I've worked on.

Roberts: We‚Äôve taken significant, important steps in ag security, especially as it relates to animal disease preparedness. We've worked to meet these challenges by ID‚Äôing vulnerabilities & enacting policies that allow the ag and food sector to be better prepared and more secure.

Roberts: We continue to learn hard and much-needed lessons about safety and security as we persevere through the COVID-19 pandemic. For years there have been research efforts devoted to the threat of animal and plant disease.

Roberts: This has been quite a year for US ag and consumers. Perhaps for the first time since the Great Depression, the significance of food security has resonated through the entire ag & food value chain, impacting nearly every kitchen table around the country & the world.

Roberts: Given the benefits this research has delivered to both urban and rural constituencies, every member of Congress should appreciate the wisdom of continuing to build on the strong foundation of agricultural research in the United States.
Roberts: Even more impressive, private sector investment in food and agriculture research rose over 660 percent over that same period‚Äî from $1.6 billion to more than $12 billion per year.

Roberts: In Fiscal Year 1981, when I began my service in the House, $1.4 billion in public funding was provided for U.S. agriculture research. By 2015, that annual investment more than tripled to more than $4.5 billion.

Roberts: We have provided certainty and predictability by transitioning to a market-oriented farm policy. We have also fostered continuous improvement in research, science, and new technologies such as biotechnology.

Roberts: Since the establishment of the land-grant university system in 1862, the country has valued and prioritized ag innovation. Kansas State, the 1st land-grant institution created under the Act, is no exception. I am proud of our policy record on behalf of American ag.

Roberts: Agriculture research drives change, efficiencies, and productivity. It is the foundation that supports our modern food system miracle. It is essential considering the growing chaos, hunger, and malnutrition in our world.

Roberts: During my time in public service, the U.S. has witnessed one of its greatest untold success stories ‚Äì federal policies that have fostered a scale and efficiency of the U.S. agriculture system that would have been unimaginable to our predecessors.

Roberts: With all of the challenges ‚Äì and opportunities ‚Äì that our agricultural producers face, it is fitting that the topic of this hearing is ‚ÄúAgricultural Research and Securing the United States Food Supply.‚Äù

Roberts: We have deliberated on a variety of issues that directly impact our constituents, including farm and nutrition programs, trade policy, rural economic development, and conservation practices, just to name a few.

Roberts: When I assumed the gavel nearly 6 years ago, I made it a priority that this committee would be a platform for America‚Äôs farmers, ranchers, small biz, rural communities, school children, and the hungry. 80+ hearings and meetings later, this Committee has done exactly that
Roberts: Both of the Agriculture Committees regularly work in a truly bipartisan effort to develop policies that best serve the diverse and dedicated industry that is American agriculture.

Roberts: Today, I am honored to hold what will probably be my final hearing as Chairman of this Committee. During the four decades that I have served in Congress, I have been a member of the Agriculture Committees in both the House and the Senate.

As a United States Senator, I wake up every day thinking I may be able to do something good for our country, and I go to bed most nights thinking that I have. 
It has been a great privilege to serve the people in Tennessee, as governor and in the United States Senate. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EoQ5AKNXUA045my.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1334253611849801741/vid/360x270/LQwIPGzsgWvQYgl4.mp4?tag=13

And, finally, please tell them that I wake up every day thinking I may be able to do something good for our country and that I go to bed most nights thinking that I have. 

Please tell them that it has been a great privilege to be a United States Senator.

Remind them that most of the rest of the world wishes they had our remarkable system of government and that the US Senate has been, and I hope continues to be, the institution that does more than any other to create broad agreements to solve great problems and unify our country.
And most of our politics is about disappointments in not reaching the high goals that we have set for ourselves, such as all men are created equal.
As the political scientist Samuel Huntington wrote, most of our arguments are about conflicts among principles with which most Americans agree.
That we are not perfect, but, as our Constitution says, we are always working to form a more perfect union.
I hope you will remind them that we live in a remarkable country with the strongest military, the best universities and 20 percent of all the money in the world for just 5 percent of the people.

On one screen are the tweets and acrimonious confirmation hearings. But on the other screen, senators are working together to strengthen national defense, national laboratories, national parks and the @NIH.
My reply is always the same: Please suggest to your students that they look at Washington, D.C., as a split screen television.
Invariably one teacher will ask, ‚ÄúSenator, what would you like us to tell our students about being a United States senator?‚Äù
My favorite time as a senator has been inviting onto the Senate floor American history teachers who are attending the academies that were established in legislation proposed in my maiden address.

Being a senator is more like bring a parade organizer. You pick the route, recruit the marchers, select the music and even pick someone else to be the drum major ‚Äî and then you walk in the middle of the parade so the marchers don‚Äôt march into the ditch.
Being governor is like being Moses. To get something done, you say, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go this way.‚Äù

Some former governors don‚Äôt like being a senator. Not me. The jobs are just different. In both jobs you pick an urgent need, develop a strategy and try to persuade at least half the people you are right.

Why join the Grand Ole Opry if you don‚Äôt want to sing? And I guarantee you that if 15 or 20 Republicans and 15 or 20 Democrats in this talented body set out to change that practice, it would change.

And the behavior that needs to change first is for individual senators to stop blocking amendments of other senators. If you are opposed to something, you ought to vote no. Why stop the entire body from considering the amendment?

You don‚Äôt have to eliminate the filibuster to restore the Senate to its traditional role of working across party lines to solve big problems. We don‚Äôt need a change of rules. The Senate needs a change of behavior.
But it‚Äôs hard to accomplish something if you don‚Äôt vote on amendments. Lately, the Senate has been like joining the Grand Ole Opry and not being allowed to sing.

It doesn‚Äôt take a genius to figure out how to gum up the works of a body of one hundred that operates mainly by unanimous consent. Here‚Äôs my view: It‚Äôs hard to get here, hard to stay here, and while you‚Äôre here, you ought to try to accomplish something good for the country.
Ending the filibuster would unleash the tyranny of the majority to steamroll the rights of the minority.

Alexis De Tocqueville, the young Frenchman who wandered through the United States in 1831 and 1832 and wrote the best book yet on Democracy in America, saw two great dangers for the young country: Russia and the tyranny of the majority.

And the filibuster‚Äîthe right to talk your head off until you force a broad agreement‚Äîis the preeminent tool we use to force those passions into a compromise that most of us can vote for and that the country can live with.
That is why the framers created the Senate, to be the cooling saucer for the passions that President Washington talked about.
Is such back and forth and back and forth what a fractured country really needs?
But what about when the other party is in charge and the freight train roars in the other direction, this time to impose National Right to Work, Pro Life and Gun Rights laws?
This is very appealing‚Äîif you are in the majority of the moment.
Let the passions of the people roar through the Senate. If you‚Äôre a Democrat: Abolish right-to-work laws. Repeal limits on abortion. Pass restriction on guns.
Now, some advocate another way to operate the Senate. End the filibuster, the Senate‚Äôs best-known tradition. Don‚Äôt worry about working across party lines. Pass everything with a majority vote.
And most of these laws were enacted during divided government, when the presidency and at least one body of Congress were of different political parties.
But those laws didn‚Äôt just pass. They passed by wide margins. The country accepted them. And they are going to be there for a long time.
Enacting these laws took a long time, much palavering, many amendments and many years. Too many years, civil rights leaders, patients, students, songwriters and conservationists would say.

And this year, the Great American Outdoors Act, the most important conservation and outdoor recreation law in 50 years. 

https://twitter.com/SenAlexander/status/1290683953251332096?s=20 QT @SenAlexander The Great American Outdoors Act is now law! 

#RestoreOurParks #GreatOutdoors
http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EelieOwX0AA3AZe.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1290670806004105222/vid/480x270/aeKjVjFMNzu4t9ph.mp4?tag=13

In 2018, a once in a generation change in the copyright laws so songwriters could be paid fairly.  

https://twitter.com/SenAlexander/status/1134240068837683200?s=20 QT @SenAlexander In October, @POTUS signed into law the most important legislation in a generation to help songwriters be paid a fair market value for their work. #MusicModernizationAct #StandWithSongwriters http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D6yJlkJXsAIcXSS.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1129428207156060160/vid/320x180/SyUlvDbx97Fyi-Ie.mp4?tag=12

We needed a Senate in 2013 to tie student loan interest rates to market rates, saving borrowers hundreds of billions of dollars.

To pass the 21st Century Cures Act‚Äîmoving medical miracles faster into patients‚Äô lives‚Äîthat bill ran off the tracks every two or three days. 

https://twitter.com/SenAlexander/status/806931003566596096?s=20 QT @SenAlexander #Cures is a #ChristmasMiracle for virtually every American ‚Äì including kids like Max! http://pbs.twimg.com/media/CzLLdYlXUAAcmLT.jpg

More recently, to fix No Child Left Behind‚Äîthere were 100 alligators in that swamp. It was a law so hard to pass that President @BarackObama called it ‚Äúa Christmas Miracle,‚Äù when, in the end, 85 senators voted for it. 

https://twitter.com/SenAlexander/status/675010116756889601?s=20 QT @SenAlexander With @POTUS signature, 50 million kids & 3.4 million teachers have an early Christmas present #ESSA http://pbs.twimg.com/media/CV4eCY_UEAAoWlH.jpg
In the 1930s, the country needed the Senate to create Social Security. After World War II, to create the United Nations. In the 1960s, Medicare. In 1978, to ratify the Panama Canal Treaty.

That‚Äôs why the motto above the presiding officer‚Äôs desk is not just one word, ‚Äúpluribus.‚Äù It is ‚ÄúE pluribus unum, out of many, one.‚Äù More than ever, our country needs a United States Senate to turn pluribus into unum, to lead the American struggle to forge unity from diversity.
But the main purpose of the Senate is to work across party lines to force broad agreements on hard issues ‚Äì creating laws that most of us can vote for and that a diverse country will accept.
The passions of the people would roar through the Senate like a freight train, like they do in the House of Representatives.
Presidents would like it. They would get their way more easily if we ended the requirement that 60 senators vote to cut off debate before we vote on a legislative issue.
Ending the filibuster would destroy the impetus in the United States Senate to force broad agreements on hard issues and unleash the tyranny of the majority to steam roll the minority.

It's been a great privilege to serve the people in Tennessee, as governor and in the United States Senate.
